title: Drop Labels from a Table
text: tidyREDCap package creates data sets labelled columns. like see labels data set demographics, can use RStudio function View(), shown .  However, functions work well labeled variables. Data summary Variable type: character Variable type: Date Variable type: numeric need way drop label variable drop labels variables dataset.
code: tidyREDCap::import_instruments(   url = "https://bbmc.ouhsc.edu/redcap/api/",   token = keyring::key_get("REDCapR_test") ) View(demographics) library(skimr)  # for the skim() function demographics |> skim()

title: Drop Labels from a Table
text: can drop label single variable drop_label() function. example: can drop labels using drop_labels() function. example: Data summary Variable type: character Variable type: numeric
code: demographics_changed <- drop_label(demographics, "name_first") demographics_without_labels <- drop_labels(demographics)  demographics_without_labels |>    skim()

title: Import All Instruments from a REDCap Project
text: See Importing REDCap vignette details/information saving API key secure location. import_instruments() function can given URL token REDCap project, like one created return one table instrument project. default, function drop empty records. example, API call pulling data REDCap project four instruments: Enrollment, Nacho Craving Index (NCI), Generalized Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD7), Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAM-). running code get four tables REDCap project.  Notice repeat HAM-record.  person done baseline assessment one record.
code: # Do not type your API token directly into your code tidyREDCap::import_instruments(   url = "https://redcap.miami.edu/api/",   token = "1A2B3CXXYYZZOOMMGOSHNOOOOX1Y2Z3" # This is BAD! )  # A better way to do this is to read the API key saved in your operating system #   For instructions on saving your API key, see link below. tidyREDCap::import_instruments(   url = "https://redcap.miami.edu/api/",    token = keyring::key_get("nacho_anxiety_key")  # This is BETTER! )

title: Make Binary Word
text: REDCap exports ‚Äúchoose apply‚Äù question series similarly-named, binary indicator variables (.e., variables equal either ‚Äúchecked‚Äù ‚Äúunchecked‚Äù). Using variables individually, obvious way detect common patterns people pick together. Example: Nacho Craving Index (NCI), respondents can indicate eight ingredients currently craving (.e., Chips, Yellow cheese, Orange cheese, White cheese, Meat, Beans, Tomatoes, Peppers). exported variables names like ingredients___1, ingredients___2, etc. REDCap, simple get summary individual variables using ‚ÄúData Exports, Reports, Stats‚Äù application within REDCap interface selecting ‚ÄúStats & Charts‚Äù. data R, simple tables can produced table() function, beautiful tables can created tabyl() adorn_pct_formatting() functions janitor package. However, univariate tables, impossible judge patterns answers marked together. example, using univariate tables, difficult tell percentage people craving chips yellow cheese.
code: redcap <- readRDS(file = "./redcap.rds")  # Chips janitor::tabyl(redcap$ingredients___1) %>%    janitor::adorn_pct_formatting() %>%    knitr::kable() # Yellow cheese janitor::tabyl(redcap$ingredients___2) %>%    janitor::adorn_pct_formatting() %>%    knitr::kable()

what: Aside: Loading REDCap Data into R
title: Make Binary Word
text: See Import Instruments REDCap Project Importing REDCap vignettes details/information.

title: Make Binary Word
text: Even subsetting REDCap data include ingredients variables, still difficult detect common patterns eight ingredients.
code: redcap <- readRDS(file = "./redcap.rds")  analysis <- redcap %>%    select(starts_with("ingredients___"))     knitr::kable(tail(analysis))

title: Make Binary Word
text: make_binary_word() function combines responses individual variables single ‚Äúword‚Äù indicates choices selected. example, first option NCI ingredient question, chips (.e., ingredients___1), checked, word created make_binary_word() begin ; checked, word start _. second option, Yellow cheese (.e., ingredients___2), checked, next letter b; otherwise, _ used placeholder. Following pattern, somebody craving eight nacho ingredients, ‚Äúword‚Äù eight underscores, one ingredient (.e., ________). Conversely, craving every ingredient, ‚Äúword‚Äù abcdefgh.

title: Make Binary Word
text: default lettering somewhat helpful, using meaningful (mnemonic) letters makes binary words easier understand. case, first letter choice can used helpful mnemonic. use custom lettering, specify vector single-letter abbreviations pass the_labels argument. sure include one unique abbreviation data frame column. example: summary table shows 20 people provide information ingredients craved. remaining people display recurring patterns, many people craved chips yellow cheese together.

title: Make a 'Choose All' Table
text: REDCap exports ‚Äúchoose apply‚Äù question series similarly-named, binary indicator variables (.e., variables equal either ‚Äúchecked‚Äù ‚Äúunchecked‚Äù). example, following data represents sample responses Nacho Craving Index. desirable concise table showing often option chosen.
code: redcap <- readRDS(file = "./redcap.rds") redcap %>%    select(starts_with("ingredients___")) %>%    head() #>   ingredients___1 ingredients___2 ingredients___3 ingredients___4 #> 1         Checked         Checked         Checked         Checked #> 2         Checked         Checked       Unchecked         Checked #> 3       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 4       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 5       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 6       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #>   ingredients___5 ingredients___6 ingredients___7 ingredients___8 #> 1         Checked         Checked       Unchecked         Checked #> 2         Checked       Unchecked         Checked         Checked #> 3       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 4       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 5       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked #> 6       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked       Unchecked

what: Aside: Loading REDCap Data into R
title: Make a 'Choose All' Table
text: See Import Instruments REDCap Project Importing REDCap vignettes details/information.

title: Make a 'Choose All' Table
text: pass make_choose_all_table() function, name REDCap export, name choose apply question question REDCap, produce concise frequency count table. Similar make_choose_one_table() function, can use function inside analysis pipeline. can add kable() call make table publication quality.
code: make_choose_all_table(redcap, "ingredients")  #> # A tibble: 8 √ó 2 #>   What          Count #>   <chr>         <dbl> #> 1 Chips             9 #> 2 Yellow cheese     7 #> 3 Orange cheese     3 #> 4 White cheese      4 #> 5 Meat              5 #> 6 Beans             7 #> 7 Tomatoes          6 #> 8 Peppers           8 redcap %>%    make_choose_all_table("ingredients") %>%    knitr::kable()

what: Data Exported with ‚ÄúData Exports, Reports and Stats‚Äù in REDCap
title: Make a 'Choose All' Table
text: export data using point--click tools built REDCap end two files, one contains R code data. run code end dataset called data contains two copies information. example, download Nacho Craving Index see ingredients variables, showing ingredients people craving, second copy variables .factor tagged end names. factor versions variable labels. need subset data drop . example shows process. Note copied data data frame meaningful name.
code: # This is the data produced by exporting using point-and-click REDCap export. manual_export <- data  manual_export |>      select(starts_with("ingredient")) |> # get all the ingredient variables   select(-ends_with(".factor")) |>     # drop the factor version of the ingredient variables   make_choose_all_table("ingredient")  # make the table

title: Make a 'Choose One' Table
text: often desirable print variable labels summary table shows count factor labels. labels exported choose apply questions, including question whichever response chosen. redundancy often unwanted, results presented professionally. example, Nacho Craving Index data, first ingredient ‚ÄúChips‚Äù. see R presents information simply printing components ingredients___1 column. can see, information quite ugly, want tabulate results instead. However, use simple table() function clean information, lose original question answer label ingredients___1. longer know question ‚Äúselect ‚Äù option information represents.
code: redcap <- readRDS(file = "./redcap.rds") redcap$ingredients___1 # What ingredients do you currently crave?: Chips #  [1] Checked   Checked   Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked Checked   #  [8] Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked Checked   Unchecked # [15] Unchecked Checked   Unchecked Unchecked Checked   Unchecked Unchecked # [22] Unchecked Checked   Unchecked Checked   Unchecked Unchecked Unchecked # [29] Unchecked Checked   # attr(,"redcapLabels") # [1] Unchecked Checked   # attr(,"redcapLevels") # [1] 0 1 # Levels: Unchecked Checked table(redcap$ingredients___1) #  # Unchecked   Checked  #        21         9

what: Aside: Loading REDCap Data into R
title: Make a 'Choose One' Table
text: See Import Instruments REDCap Project Importing REDCap vignettes details/information.

title: Make a 'Choose One' Table
text: make_choose_one_table() function can used factor variable tabulate response preserving question checked option context. , output can molded publication-ready table single additional function call. ingredients currently crave?: Chips subset option, set TRUE, cause function remove label‚Äôs text show response option (.e., repeat ‚Äúingredients currently crave?‚Äù question). Yellow cheese function can also used analysis pipeline data frame name name factor inside data frame. example: ingredients currently crave?: Orange cheese
code: make_choose_one_table(redcap$ingredients___1)  # What ingredients do you currently crave?: Chips #   Response  n percent #  Unchecked 21     70% #    Checked  9     30% make_choose_one_table(redcap$ingredients___1) %>%    knitr::kable() make_choose_one_table(   redcap$ingredients___2,   subset = TRUE ) %>%    knitr::kable() redcap %>%    make_choose_one_table(ingredients___3) %>%    knitr::kable()

title: Make an Instrument
text: REDCap exports longitudinal projects one record (line data) per assessment (typically 1 line per day). works well every instrument/questionnaire given every assessment. Still, projects different instruments/questionnaires given different days, REDCap exports empty values (represented value NA R). Example: Nachos Anxiety project, three instruments used; different administration schedule. Subjects‚Äô anxiety assessed baseline Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7) scale. Every day, assessed Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAM-), Nacho Craving Index administered baseline end study (see figure clarification). instruments assessed every day appear entirely blank questionnaires data exported. example, values NCI instrument shown missing Day 1, Day 2, Day 3 (administered visits). R, data displayed often helpful make different data table values questionnaire without blank records.
code: redcap <- readRDS(file = "./redcap_nacho_anxiety.rds")  redcap %>%    select(     # Select these two columns     record_id, redcap_event_name,     # And also select all columns between "nachos" and "nci_complete"     nachos:nci_complete   ) %>%    # Make the table pretty   knitr::kable()

what: Aside: Loading REDCap Data into R
title: Make an Instrument
text: See Import Instruments REDCap Project Importing REDCap vignettes details/information.

title: Make an Instrument
text: Pass make_instrument() function name dataset names first last variables instrument, return table non-empty records instrument. example, extract enrollment/consent instrument: extract nacho craving information: make analysis dataset containing NCI values without subject ID event name:
code: make_instrument(redcap, "concented", "enrollment_complete") %>%    knitr::kable() make_instrument(redcap, "nachos", "nci_complete") %>%    knitr::kable() make_instrument(   redcap,   "nachos", "nci_complete",   drop_which_when = TRUE ) %>%    knitr::kable()

what: Loading REDCap Data into R with an API request
title: Importing from REDCap
text: people use ‚ÄúData Exports, Reports Stats‚Äù Application built REDCap, another handy method get data REDCap API request. API allows one program request data another program. example, add-package R can request data instance REDCap. Obviously, R package can type user name password. Instead, store API token, password, machine ask R look token pass REDCap whenever want data. used two R packages access REDCap projects,redcapAPI REDCapR. Unfortunately, redcapAPI longer actively developed, run problems . lovely benefit exporting variables, basically using variable names see REDCap, tagging variables ‚Äúlabels‚Äù subjects viewed completing forms. taken labeling functionality added tidyREDCap.

title: Importing from REDCap
text: functions allow export data need give API token. Remember, information username password. NEVER type directly code. REDCap API key ‚Äú1A2B3CXXYYZZOOMMGOSHNOOOOX1Y2Z3‚Äù : , anybody gets copy code able access REDCap project. Also, whenever run line code, API token saved R history files.
code: # Do not type your API token directly into your code tidyREDCap::import_instruments(   "https://redcap.miami.edu/api/",   "1A2B3CXXYYZZOOMMGOSHNOOOOX1Y2Z3" # This is BAD! )

previous_headings: Loading REDCap Data into R with an API request > Protecting Your API Tokens
title: Importing from REDCap
text: can save API keys operating system‚Äôs built-password manager (.e., macOS Keychain, Windows Credential Manager, Secret Service API (GNOME Keyring/KWallet) Linux). several packages available . recommend using either keyring shelter. shelter solid choice users working multiple operating systems. primarily work one operating system, recommend using keyring. save key, use code like : box appear can enter key. , can access key like : future, operating system may ask enter computer‚Äôs password access key. want use redcapAPI REDCapR packages directly can use trickery pass API key functions. example: curious, made help files, saved data using saveRDS() function.
code: install.packages("pak") pak::pak("keyring") keyring::key_set("nacho_anxiety_key") tidyREDCap::import_instruments(   url = "https://redcap.miami.edu/api/",    token = keyring::key_get("nacho_anxiety_key") ) rcon <- redcapAPI::redcapConnection(   url = 'https://redcap.miami.edu/api/',    token = keyring::key_get("nacho_anxiety_key") )  redcap <- redcapAPI::exportRecords(rcon) rcon <- redcapAPI::redcapConnection(   url = 'https://redcap.miami.edu/api/',    token = keyring::key_get("nacho_anxiety_key") )  redcap <- redcapAPI::exportRecords(rcon)  saveRDS(redcap, file = "redcap.rds")

TRUE default. record_id Name record_id variable (changed REDCap). first_record_id value custom record_id variable (changed REDCap).  improve speed import, tidyREDCap pulls single record twice.  default uses first record.  custom record_id variable first record identifier 1,  specify record identifier value .  example using dude_id instead record_id dude_id value "first dude" one records argument first_record_id = "first dude". envir name environment tables saved.

title: Convert a
text: function takes data frame holding binary variables values corresponding dummy-coded "choose apply" question. can used binary word problem.

title: Convert a
code: make_binary_word(df, yes_value = "Checked", the_labels = letters)

title: Convert a
text: df data frame variables corresponding binary indicators (dummy coded variables) "choose apply" question. yes_value character string corresponds choosing "yes" binary variables df. Defaults REDCap "Checked" option. the_labels character vector single letters holding letters used make binary word. See article/vignette called "Make Binary Word" example: https://raymondbalise.github.io/tidyREDCap/articles/makeBinaryWord.html.

title: Convert a
text: character vector length equal rows df, including one letter underscore column df. instance, df one column eight options Nacho Craving Index example instrument (https://libguides.du.edu/c.php?g=948419&p=6839916), row containing values "Chips" (checked), "Yellow cheese" (unchecked), "Orange cheese" (checked), "White cheese" (checked), "Meat" (checked), "Beans" (unchecked), "Tomatoes" (unchecked) "Peppers" (checked), character string corresponding row "a_cde__h". underscores represent options "Yellow cheese", "Beans", "Tomatoes" left unchecked.

title: Convert a
code: test_df <- tibble::tibble(   q1 = c("Unchecked", "Checked"),   q2 = c("Unchecked", "Unchecked"),   q3 = c("Checked", "Checked"),   q4 = c("Checked", "Unchecked") ) make_binary_word(test_df) #> [1] "__cd" "a_c_"

title: make_yes_no ‚Äî make_yes_no
text: Convert "Yes-", "True-False" "Checkboxes (Multiple Answers)" question REDCap factor holding "Yes" "Unknown". Technically "yes" "checked" (ignoring case), 1 TRUE responses converted "Yes" values "Unknown". Also see make_yes_no_unknown().

text: factor "Yes" "Unknown"

title: make_yes_no ‚Äî make_yes_no
code: make_yes_no(c(0, 1, NA)) #> [1] No or Unknown Yes           No or Unknown #> Levels: No or Unknown Yes make_yes_no(c("unchecked", "Checked", NA)) #> [1] No or Unknown Yes           No or Unknown #> Levels: No or Unknown Yes

title: make_yes_no_unknown ‚Äî make_yes_no_unknown
text: Convert "Yes-", "True-False" "Checkboxes (Multiple Answers)" question REDCap factor holding "" "Yes" "Unknown". Technically "yes" "checked" (ignoring case), 1 TRUE responses converted "Yes". "" "unchecked" (ignoring case), 0 FALSE converted "".  values set "Unknown". Also see make_yes_no().

title: tidyREDCap 1.1.3 (CRAN release)
text: Update vignettes suggest keyring. Package now depends R >= 4.1.0 use pipe operator. Fixed vignette URLs causing site redirection issues automated CRAN checks. Added alt text vignette images.

title: tidyREDCap 1.1.2 (CRAN release)
text: CRAN release: 2024-09-16 Fix issues reported CRAN Linux old R Windows (4.3.3) saying Update roxygen2 version (Thank Beasley) Fix .data$ depreciated tidyselect (https://github.com/r-lib/tidyselect/issues/169) Fixed missing global bindings caused tidyselect fix.
